title: 103_hr2026
content:
The "Renewables and Energy Efficiency Incentives Act of 1993" allows energy-related credits to offset 25 percent of minimum tax under Title I for the production and use of renewable energy sources. The "Renewables and Energy Efficiency Incentives Act of 1993" permits energy credits to offset 25 percent of the minimum tax for renewable energy production and use. The "Renewables and Energy Efficiency Incentives Act of 1993" allows energy credits to offset a portion of the minimum tax for renewable energy production and use. The amendment made by subsection (a) reduces the limitation under paragraph (1) by the energy credit allowed under subsection (a) for taxable years starting after December 31, 1993. SEC. 102 of the "Renewables and Energy Efficiency Incentives Act of 1993" amends the definition of energy property to include small wind turbines with a rated capacity of 50 kilowatts or less. This equipment must not be primarily used for selling electricity to an unrelated person. The amendment applies to property placed in service after December 31, 1993. SEC. 104 amends the energy credit requirements for equipment using solar energy, stating that it must have an average annual use of non-solar energy below 50%. The amendment applies to property placed in service after December 31, 1993. TITLE II--INCENTIVES TO PROMOTE ENERGY EFFICIENCY

SEC. 201. Large electric trucks, vans, and buses eligible for deduction for clean-fuel vehicles. Amends the definition of qualified clean-fuel vehicle property to exclude certain vehicles. Denies credit for vehicles that are eligible for deduction. Effective date is after December 31, 1993. SEC. 197. ENERGY CONSERVATION EXPENDITURES BY ELECTRIC AND GAS UTILITIES. Part VI of subchapter B of chapter 1 is amended to allow deductions for energy conservation expenditures by certain utilities. In the case of an electric or gas utility, a deduction is allowed for energy conservation expenditures paid or incurred during the taxable year. Energy conservation expenditures include subsidies for devices or services to reduce energy consumption, energy consulting, and audits for commercial, residential, and industrial properties. The term 'energy conservation expenditures' includes costs for devices or services to reduce energy consumption, consulting, and audits for commercial, residential, and industrial properties. It does not include expenses used to determine the basis of depreciable property owned by the taxpayer. The term 'electric or gas utility' refers to corporations providing electric energy, natural gas, or steam with established or approved rates. The text discusses amendments to section 263(a) regarding deductions for energy conservation expenditures. Amendments include adding a new subparagraph (H) for deductions allowed under section 197. SEC. 197 discusses energy conservation expenditures by electric and gas utilities, with amendments applying to expenditures after December 31, 1980. SEC. 203 provides a full exclusion for energy conservation subsidies related to nonresidential property. SEC. 301 amends the exclusion of energy conservation subsidies provided by public utilities for the purchase or installation of energy conservation measures. Effective after December 31, 1993. The reduction of credit for ethanol blenders and fuel tax subsidies is amended by decreasing the cents per gallon rates for alcohol used as fuel and gasoline mixed with alcohol at refinery. The reduction in special fuels tax for qualified methanol and ethanol fuel is amended by decreasing the rate from 5.4 cents to 3.5 cents. These amendments will take effect on January 1, 1994. SEC. 302. Repeal of exclusion for interest on bonds issued to finance electric generating facilities fueled by coal, petroleum, or nuclear power. The amendment states that bonds used to finance certain electric generating facilities utilizing nuclear power, coal, crude oil, or petroleum products will not be tax-exempt. This applies to bonds issued after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 303 repeals tax-exempt status for electric cooperatives, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 1993. SEC. 304 increases taxes on crude oil. SEC. 304 increases taxes on crude oil by adding a new petroleum security rate of 5 cents per barrel, effective January 1, 1994. SEC. 306 repeals the exception from passive loss limitation for working interests in oil and gas properties, effective for taxable years beginning after December 31, 1993. The amendment to section 469(c) removes paragraphs (3) and redesignates paragraphs (4) through (6) as paragraphs (3) through (5). It also makes a conforming amendment to paragraph (3) by adjusting the heading and text. These changes apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 1993.
